content.body: Have a nice summer folks
The same to you all Have a wonderful summer vacation
https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#serialize-an-integer is entertainingly succinct. No idea what data type it returns for example :)
I found https://github.com/whatwg/infra/issues/201, so now I know fetch has a very slight improvement on this, which has apparently been copied into various other specs.
A decimal number is a data type :p
Anyway, yeah, we should add numbers and ways to serialize them to strings to Infra. Maybe now that BigInt is defined we can actually do so.

content.body: I guess `parent browsing context` got changed to something else at some point before March?
content.formatted_body: I guess parent browsing context got changed to something else at some point before March?

content.body: aha, `parent navigable`, it seems
content.formatted_body: aha, parent navigable, it seems

content.body: * aha, `parent navigable`, it seems. Right?
content.formatted_body: * aha, parent navigable, it seems. Right?

content.body: Yeah, though I'm not sure it's really a term of art on its own; you'd get the current navigable somehow and then grab its parent member.
I see
Lemme grab the relevant part of the credential-management spec

https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-credential-management/#algorithm-same-origin-with-ancestors
> 6. While _current_ has a parent browsing context:
>
>    1. Set _current_ to current’s parent browsing context.
content.formatted_body:
https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-credential-management/#algorithm-same-origin-with-ancestors

  1. While current has a parent browsing context:

    1. Set current to current’s parent browsing context.

content.body: So I guess I can’t just `s/parent browsing context/parent navigable/` there?
content.formatted_body: So I guess I can’t just s/parent browsing context/parent navigable/ there?

content.body: Maybe I need to add some earlier step to get the current navigable first?
_current_ prolly needs to become a navigable and then you check _current_'s parent
content.formatted_body: current prolly needs to become a navigable and then you check current's parent

content.body: It looks like you want to go from document -> navigable. For that, use "node navigable".

content.body: sideshowbarker: I think that's because it lacks input as argument so you either want to remove input in link-defaults or add it where you reference
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: I think that's because it lacks input as argument so you either want to remove input in link-defaults or add it where you reference

content.body: sideshowbarker: in fact if you did `fetch()` you'd probably not need link-defaults
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: in fact if you did <a lt=fetch(input)><code>fetch()</code></a> you'd probably not need link-defaults

content.body: hi all, edgecase with `HTMLStyleElement` for you: if the disabled flag is set and the children are updated, should the stylesheet be updated/applied?
content.formatted_body: hi all, edgecase with HTMLStyleElement for you: if the disabled flag is set and the children are updated, should the stylesheet be updated/applied?

example:

const style = document.createElement("style")
style.disabled = true;
assert(style.disabled); // true
style.textContent = "new content";
assert(!style.disabled); // false

m.new_content.formatted_body:
example:

const style = document.createElement("style");
document.body.appendChild(style);

style.disabled = true;
assert(style.disabled); // true

style.textContent = "new content";
assert(!style.disabled); // false

example:

const style = document.createElement("style");
document.body.appendChild(style);

style.disabled = true;
style.disabled // true

style.textContent = "new content";
style.disabled // false
